name: Palau
description: Palau, known as the ‘Lost Paradise,’ is a small island nation in the western Pacific Ocean, comprised of over 300 islands, of which only about 240 are inhabited.  It’s renowned for its stunning coral reefs, diverse marine life, and rich cultural heritage. Palau boasts a unique blend of pristine natural beauty and a commitment to conservation, making it a globally significant destination for ecotourism and scientific research.

quickFacts.label: Official Name
quickFacts.description: The official name of the nation.
quickFacts.detail: Formally recognized in 1994, Palau gained independence from the United States.

quickFacts.label: Population
quickFacts.detail: The population is concentrated on the rocky islands and the main island of Babeldaob.

quickFacts.label: Capital
quickFacts.detail: Located on Babeldaob, the largest island.

quickFacts.label: Area
quickFacts.description: The total land area of Palau.
quickFacts.detail: This small nation comprises over 300 islands.

quickFacts.label: Currency
quickFacts.detail: Palau adopted the US Dollar as its official currency in 1995.

quickFacts.label: Languages
quickFacts.detail: Palauan is a Micronesian language, and English is widely spoken due to its role in tourism and education.

quickFacts.label: GDP
quickFacts.description: The Gross Domestic Product of Palau.
quickFacts.detail: Primarily driven by tourism and fisheries.

climateData.title: Palau Climate
climateData.description: Palau experiences a tropical maritime climate characterized by consistently warm temperatures and high humidity throughout the year. Rainfall is abundant, particularly during the wet season, and influences the lush vegetation and vibrant coral reefs.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Dry Season
seasonalCharacteristics.description: The dry season offers the best weather for diving and exploring the islands, with lower humidity and fewer rain showers.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Wet Season
seasonalCharacteristics.description: The wet season brings frequent rainfall, often in the form of short, intense showers. Despite the rain, the islands remain beautiful and the marine life is abundant.

naturalWonders.name: Jellyfish Lake
naturalWonders.description: Jellyfish Lake is a unique marine lake teeming with millions of non-stinging jellyfish. Visitors can swim amongst these gentle creatures in a surreal and unforgettable experience.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The lake is completely enclosed by a limestone ridge, preventing the jellyfish from escaping. The jellyfish have evolved to lose their stinging cells, creating a safe environment for swimming. The lake's color varies from turquoise to emerald green due to the algae that thrive in the water.
viewingTips: Wear a dark-colored swimsuit to avoid attracting attention from the jellyfish.

naturalWonders.name: Rock Islands Southern Lagoon
naturalWonders.description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site, the Rock Islands Southern Lagoon is a stunning archipelago of limestone islands covered in lush vegetation and surrounded by vibrant coral reefs.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The islands are remnants of an ancient coral reef that has been slowly eroded by the sea over millions of years. They provide habitat for a diverse range of marine and terrestrial species, including endangered sea turtles and Palau's national bird, the flycatcher.
viewingTips: Take a guided boat tour to explore the islands.
Snorkel or dive in the coral reefs.

naturalWonders.name: Babeldaob
naturalWonders.description: Babeldaob is the largest island in Palau, offering a diverse landscape of volcanic mountains, lush rainforests, and pristine beaches.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The island is home to the nation’s capital, Ngerulmud, and several traditional villages. It’s a great place to experience Palauan culture and explore the island’s natural beauty.
viewingTips: Visit the traditional villages to learn about Palauan culture.
Hike to the summit of Ngardmau volcano.

ecosystemData.title: Palau Ecosystems
ecosystemData.overview: Palau’s ecosystems are remarkably diverse and fragile, shaped by its unique geological history and isolation. The nation’s commitment to conservation has resulted in significant protection of its natural resources.

biodiversityCategories.name: Coral Reefs
biodiversityCategories.description: Palau’s coral reefs are among the most diverse and pristine in the world, supporting a vast array of marine life.

statistics.details: Over 300 species of coral have been identified.
More than 600 species of fish inhabit the reefs.

notableSpecies.name: Manta Ray
notableSpecies.significance: A keystone species in the reef ecosystem.

notableSpecies.name: Green Sea Turtle
notableSpecies.significance: An important herbivore that helps maintain the health of the coral reefs.

biodiversityCategories.name: Rainforests
biodiversityCategories.description: Palau’s rainforests are home to a wealth of endemic plant and animal species, many of which are found nowhere else on Earth.

statistics.details: Over 200 species of trees thrive in the rainforests.
More than 40 species of birds call the rainforests home.

notableSpecies.name: Palauan Flycatcher
notableSpecies.significance: Palau’s national bird, endemic to the islands.

notableSpecies.name: Palauan Gecko
notableSpecies.significance: A unique gecko species found only in Palau.

activities.title: Palau Activities
activities.description: Palau offers a wide range of activities for visitors, from diving and snorkeling to hiking and cultural experiences.

activityCategories.name: Diving & Snorkeling
activityCategories.description: Explore Palau’s world-renowned coral reefs and encounter diverse marine life.

activities.name: Reef Diving
activities.description: Dive amongst vibrant coral reefs and encounter colorful fish, sharks, and rays.

activities.name: Snorkeling
activities.description: Explore the shallow reefs and observe marine life without diving.

activityCategories.name: Hiking & Trekking
activityCategories.description: Discover Palau’s diverse landscapes, from volcanic mountains to lush rainforests.

activities.name: Ngardmau Volcano Hike
activities.description: Hike to the summit of Palau’s highest volcano.
